title: Session cookie can be leaked over an unencrypted HTTP connection

profile.name: IRCCloud
profile.about: Group chat for teams, friends, and communities. IRCCloud is an IRC client with a future. Stay connected, chat from anywhere, and never miss a message.

vulnerability_information: Because the session cookie, `session`, does not have the [Secure flag](https://www.owasp.org/index.php/SecureFlag) set, it is possible that the session cookie leaks over an unencrypted connection. An attacker could exploit this issue by (for example) tricking a user into clicking on a link to a page with the following HTML code: When the user visits the page, the browser will send a request to www.irccloud.com, over an unencrypted connection (note the **http** instead of **https**), containing the session cookie. When this happens, an attacker can easily take over the user's session with a *Man-In-The-Middle attack*. I recommend setting the Secure flag, so browsers who support the Secure flag will prevent the transmission of a cookie in an unencrypted HTTP packet.
vulnerability_information_html:
Because the session cookie, session, does not have the Secure flag set, it is possible that the session cookie leaks over an unencrypted connection. An attacker could exploit this issue by (for example) tricking a user into clicking on a link to a page with the following HTML code:

<img src="http://www.irccloud.com">

When the user visits the page, the browser will send a request to www.irccloud.com, over an unencrypted connection (note the http instead of https), containing the session cookie. When this happens, an attacker can easily take over the user's session with a Man-In-The-Middle attack.

I recommend setting the Secure flag, so browsers who support the Secure flag will prevent the transmission of a cookie in an unencrypted HTTP packet.

activities.message:
Thanks very much for your report!

We've taken a look into this and it is a bug which our internal security processes had already identified. We're aiming to get it resolved shortly.

activities.message:
Thanks again, we've made sure the Secure flag is now always set in cookies. However, since the issue was first reported in bug #6877 (public disclosure requested, pending reporter approval) your report is ineligible for a bounty.

For the record, this was an issue affecting cookies set by our javascript, and not by the Set-cookie header sent back in HTTP responses.
